I'm fighting with my colleagues, @HouseDemocrats, to defend and strengthen the ACA #ForThePeople. We can't afford to lose this fight. #DefendTheACA https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/3/26/18282103/aca-obamacare-news-house-democrats-legislation-doj …

GONE: Support for rural hospitals. As Americans lose coverage, already struggling hospitals will be hit even harder.

GONE: Ban on insurance companies having lifetime caps on coverage.

GONE: Requirements that insurance companies cover prescription drugs and maternity care.

GONE: 2.3 million individuals will no longer be able to stay on their parents’ insurance.

GONE: Insurance companies will be able to charge women 50 percent more than men.

GONE: Financial assistance that helps 9 million people purchase health care in the marketplace.

GONE: Protections for 130 million Americans with pre-existing conditions. 

GONE: Medicaid expansion, which covers 17 million people.

GONE: Nearly 12 million seniors will have to pay more for prescription drugs

The Administration is trying to tear apart the United States health care system by going to court to eliminate the Affordable Care Act in its entirety. We can't let that happen. This is some of what will be lost if the #ACA is struck down: [THREAD]

#ICYMI: I'm thankful to the many local, state, and business leaders who participated in yesterday's day-long, five-stop #MA3Infrastructure tour, but also the reporters who came out to tell the story of infrastructure in our communities. You can read about some of our day below:
I am thankful to have been a part of this thoughtful, important conversation. https://twitter.com/JRosenworcel/status/1118258231921582085 …

...but to do so in a bold, green, and modern way while putting American's back to work. This tour highlighted some of the enormous potential that exists across #MA3 and the Commonwealth. It will take smart investments now, and I look forward to fighting for those investments.

I am thankful to all those who participated in today's #MA3Infrastructure tour, which stretched across Fitchburg, Marlborough, Ayer, Lowell, and Haverhill. There's no question that Congress must act #ForThePeople not only to rebuild America's crumbling infrastructure...

I'm grateful for the participation and insight from @mrwc_'s Board Chair Dan Graovac and Co-Directors Christina Eckert and John Macone; @GndwkLawrence Executive Director Heather McMann, and City Councillor Melinda Barrett. #MA3
Following the presentation we were able to walk across the Basiliere Bridge to view the river and discuss the emergence of various green infrastructure initiatives.

STOP FIVE, our final stop of today's #MA3Infrastructure tour, wraps up at the @ihub_uml in Haverhill w/ @mrwc_ to discuss their work, general conversation about the Merrimack River and its importance to the regional environment and economy, and how it relates to infrastructure. pic.twitter.com/mdqDEEVEI4
...Craig Thomas, Director of Economic Development Andrew Shapiro, and Transportation Engineer Natasha Vance. #MA3

Something that always comes up in conversations about revitalization are brownfield sites. Lack of clarity on perceived contamination and the costs of clean-up limit the ability to develop land across the City resulting in many areas being underutilized or vacant.

... job creation and industrial resurgence. Over the course of planning, it was deemed necessary to undergo a process to realign Tanner Street at the Plain Street intersection, which I learned more about.

STOP FOUR of today's #MA3Infrastructure tour brings us to my hometown of Lowell, where I'm reviewing the Ayer’s City Industrial Park Urban Revitalization & Development Plan. This plan seeks to revitalize a traditionally industrial area of town to help drive the next decade of... pic.twitter.com/Hb5WT38jEK

I've also cosponsored two pieces of legislation to protect veterans and firefighters who may have been exposed to PFAS.

BREAKING: The House just voted to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act (#VAWA), H.R. 1585. 

My full statement here: https://trahan.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=98 …

The reauthorization makes critical new investments in abuse prevention, enhances vital law enforcement tools, bolsters support resources for survivors, and much more. Every American -- every woman -- has the right to live free from abuse.

Each time Congress has reauthorized VAWA, they have strengthened it to improve protections and access to safety and justice for survivors.

I was proud to continue in that tradition today by voting in favor of this VAWA reauthorization.

Domestic violence remains far too common with as many as one in three women in the United States still experiencing abuse. The landmark Violence Against Women Act of 1994 ushered in transformative progress by calling for the protection of all Americans from violence and abuse. https://twitter.com/NPR/status/1113844078817501185 …
